page.title: 03Flora of Fritton Common
page.content: {Fritton Common}is an area of{biotic {climax grassland}approximately 0.75km by 0.25km. The western side is edged by mature oak, sycamore, and horse- chestnut trees and a plum tree. A variety of pondweeds, duckweeds, watercress, watermint, and species of rush can be seen in nearby ponds. Of the{twenty grass species}found on the common,{ten distinctive grass {inflourescences}can be seen in{June; they include the robust Cock's Foot and Tufted Hair Grass,the upright Meadow Foxtail and Meadow Grasses, the small Red and Yellow Fescues, the Scented Sweet Vernal and islands of Brown Bent Grass and Yorkshire Fog. In late June the distinctive flowers of Sorrell and Meadow Buttercup form a red and yellow carpet over the Common, whilst less prominant flora include Daisy, Bedstraws and a solitary Orchid
